articles.headline: White House Weighs Actions to Deter Overseas Tax Flight
articles.snippet: Treasury officials are assembling an array of options that would wipe out the enticements of so-called tax inversions.
articles.abstract: Treasury officials are assembling an array of options that would wipe out the enticements of so-called tax inversions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is weighing plans to circumvent Congress and act on its own to curtail tax benefits for United States companies that relocate overseas to lower their tax bills, seeking to stanch a recent wave of so-called corporate inversions, Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Russian Hackers Amass Over a Billion Internet Passwords
articles.snippet: The hacked records, discovered by a security firm based in Milwaukee, include user name and password combinations and more than 500 million email addresses.
articles.abstract: The hacked records, discovered by a security firm based in Milwaukee, include user name and password combinations and more than 500 million email addresses.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Russian crime ring has amassed the largest known collection of stolen Internet credentials, including 1.2 billion user name and password combinations and more than 500 million email addresses, security researchers say.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and David Gelles

articles.headline: After Pushback, Murdoch Abandons Fox’s Pursuit of Time Warner
articles.snippet: It would have created a $150 billion giant, but Time Warner and Fox’s shareholders weren’t interested.
articles.abstract: It would have created a $150 billion giant, but Time Warner and Fox’s shareholders weren’t interested.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:12 p.m. |  At 4:07 p.m. Tuesday, the chief executive of Time Warner Inc., Jeffrey L. Bewkes, received an unexpected email.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and JONATHAN MAHLER

articles.headline: Reducing Carbon by Curbing Population
articles.snippet: Concern about climate change has reignited interest in finding ways to reduce the pace of population growth.
articles.abstract: Concern about climate change has reignited interest in finding ways to reduce the pace of population growth.

articles.headline: Tony Blair Has Used His Connections to Change the World, and to Get Rich
articles.snippet: Since leaving Downing Street, Mr. Blair has become a diplomat, opened charities and made millions from consulting, raising questions about possible conflicts of interest.
articles.abstract: Since leaving Downing Street, Mr. Blair has become a diplomat, opened charities and made millions from consulting, raising questions about possible conflicts of interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Not long after stepping down as prime minister in 2007, Tony Blair had drinks at a hotel overlooking the River Thames with Paul Kagame, Rwanda’s president. Mr. Blair was planning a charity that would embed Western experts in finance and government in African state ministries, and he said he wanted to begin in Rwanda.

articles.headline: Federal Reserve and F.D.I.C. Fault Big Banks’ ‘Living Wills’
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve and the F.D.I.C. criticized plans that big banks had prepared for winding themselves down in a controlled fashion.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve and the F.D.I.C. criticized plans that big banks had prepared for winding themselves down in a controlled fashion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congress’s overhaul of the financial system aims to reshape large banks so that if they get into trouble they can descend into an orderly bankruptcy that does not set off a wider panic.

articles.headline: British Bank Standard Chartered Faces Action, Again, by New York State
articles.snippet: The British banking giant is being scrutinized by New York’s financial regulator for failing to weed out risky transactions flowing through its American operations.
articles.abstract: The British banking giant is being scrutinized by New York’s financial regulator for failing to weed out risky transactions flowing through its American operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standard Chartered is living the Wall Street version of “Groundhog Day.”
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Civilian or Not? New Fight in Tallying the Dead From the Gaza Conflict
articles.snippet: The battle over casualty statistics in Gaza rages on, with no other number as contentious as the ratio of civilians to combatants killed.
articles.abstract: The battle over casualty statistics in Gaza rages on, with no other number as contentious as the ratio of civilians to combatants killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Inside the Health Sciences Library at Al-Shifa Hospital here, a small team spent the war crunching numbers. Stuck to their laptops were a statistician, a graphic designer, a data-entry specialist and an issuer of death certificates, some of whom spent nights sleeping in their straight-backed chairs.

articles.headline: $11 Billion Later, High-Speed Rail Is Inching Along
articles.snippet: Although Republican opposition and community protests have slowed efforts to upgrade passenger service, policy experts and members of both parties also blame missteps by the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: Although Republican opposition and community protests have slowed efforts to upgrade passenger service, policy experts and members of both parties also blame missteps by the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — High-speed rail was supposed to be President Obama’s signature transportation project, but despite the administration spending nearly $11 billion since 2009 to develop faster passenger trains, the projects have gone mostly nowhere and the United States still lags far behind Europe and China.

articles.headline: Lyft Hopes to Coax Commuters to Leave Their Cars
articles.snippet: With Lyft Line, a new service first being offered in San Francisco, the company’s founders hope to make ride-sharing part of the workday routine.
articles.abstract: With Lyft Line, a new service first being offered in San Francisco, the company’s founders hope to make ride-sharing part of the workday routine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Today, like every weekday, about three-quarters of the nation’s adult workers — more than 100 million Americans — drove to work alone. It was ever thus: Americans, it seems, just don’t like to travel together.
